Message.Title: "The economic policy challenge facing the president is to put in place a credible deficit-reduction plan necessary to underpin economic recovery and confidence in the full faith and credit of the [United States].
Message.Msg: Chicago politics, including lying about Benghazi, won't solve this little problem. Chances of putting together a CREDIBLE DEFICIT-REDUCTION PLAN by the Obama Bozos is ZERO: FRANKFURT (MarketWatch) -- President Barack Obama won't enjoy a fiscal honeymoon after winning re-election, with pressure on U.S. officials to resolve the so-called fiscal cliff and other issues in order to maintain the country's AAA credit rating, Fitch Ratings said Wednesday. "The economic policy challenge facing the president is to put in place a credible deficit-reduction plan necessary to underpin economic recovery and confidence in the full faith and credit of the [United States]. Resolution of these fiscal policy choices would likely result in the U.S. retaining its AAA status from Fitch," the firm said. Failure to avoid the fiscal cliff -- a combination of tax hikes and spending cuts that will come into effect on Jan. 1 unless politicians reach a budget deal -- and raise the country's debt ceiling in a timely manner would likely result in a downgrade in 2013, said Fitch, which has a negative outlook on the U.S. credit rating. Rival firm Standard & Poor's last year stripped the U.S. of its AAA rating on debt worries.

Topic.Title: mrstan: your candidate, Michelle Bachmann, may lose. Patriotic Americans HATE extremists.

Message.Msg: Look what the nazi b*i*t*c*h* had to do to keep her congressional seat: David Bailey Reuters 5:35 a.m. CST, November 7, 2012 MINNEAPOLIS (Reuters) - Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota, known for controversial comments and a bid for the Republican presidential nomination, was projected to win re-election over Democratic challenger businessman Jim Graves early on Wednesday. Bachmann led Graves by 3,256 votes - or just under 1 percentage point - out of more than 351,000 votes cast in the Minnesota 6th Congressional District with 98.2 percent of precincts reporting, according to unofficial state elections returns. Minnesota law only requires a recount if the margin of victory is less than half a percentage point. CNN projected Bachmann the winner. A champion of the Tea Party movement for smaller government and conservative on social issues such as abortion and gay rights, Bachmann was running in what has been regarded as the most conservative-leaning district in Minnesota. Her bid for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination raised her name recognition nationally, but left her vulnerable in her race for a fourth term to accusations by Graves that she was not representing district interests. Some of her remarks, including an insistence on a link between an aide to Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and the Muslim Brotherhood, were denounced by some in her own party. Bachmann, a former Minnesota state senator, has never won more than 53 percent of the vote in the district and won by only 3 percentage points in the last presidential election year of 2008. The redrawing of districts after the 2010 census put Bachmann, who lives in Stillwater near the Minnesota border with Wisconsin, outside of the sprawling district that takes in suburbs to the east, north and west of Minneapolis and St. Paul and stretches northwest to include farms and smaller cities. It was the nation's most expensive House race in terms of both money raised and spent by the candidates as of mid October, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. The candidates had raised a total of $22.7 million and spent $20.8, the center reported, but Bachmann had outspent Graves by more than twelve-to-one. Bachmann sought to tag Graves, founder of the AmericInn hotel chain and now the head of Graves Hospitality, as a supporter of President Barack Obama's health reform law in television ads early in the campaign. Later Bachmann commercials portrayed the congresswoman as focused on the needs of district residents and able to work across party lines to reach goals. Graves, who describes himself as fiscally conservative, has said there are positives in the Obama healthcare program, but the "heavy lifting" has not yet begun. Graves also has said he believes Bachmann has been ineffective as a congresswoman.

Message.Title: What Is the Fiscal Cliff and Why Should We Care?
Message.Msg: What is it? The “fiscal cliff” is what Federal Reserve Board Chairman Ben Bernanke has called the many major fiscal events that could happen simultaneously at the close of 2012 and the dawning of 2013. The events include the expiration of the Bush era tax cuts, the payroll tax cut and other important tax-relief provisions. They also include the first installment of the $1.2 trillion across-the-board cuts of domestic and defense programs required under last summer’s bipartisan deficit reduction agreement. At the same time, lawmakers may have to raise the debt ceiling once again, potentially triggering another standoff in Congress.

Message.Msg: Things are going well, thanks for asking. It's soooo beautiful here, the air is much much cleaner thanks to EPA and state initiatives. The beaches/surfing are un-friggin-real gorgeous...but of course need constant care and nurturing. The forests, of massive Sequoia, towering Redwood, quaking Aspen,sacred woods of all kinds, are finally protected although 99% of old-growth has been turned into things like junk mail and campaign signs. The oceans, o my gawd, the oceans. I caught a 45 pound albacore tuna some years ago, my first, that was so stunningly sleek and gorgeous (think Ferrari with irridescent paint and Stealth plane wings) that I almost tossed it back in (I didn't..I ate it over a period of months...grilled, steamed, marinated, o man). Oh yes, the new federally-protected Marine Sanctuaries, established recently in places like the Channel Islands (Anacapa) are now amazing oases of rejuvenated, highly-varied fish species. On a recent scuba trip, I was approached, and circled, multiple times by a Giant Seabass the size of a Volkswagen! He/she was obviously quite curious, eyeing me with apparent bemusement. And the seals will actually stick their faces right up against your facemask in curiousity, and somehow you can smell their fishy breath underwater! So cool. Mountains? Message.Title: Liberty-Dick Morris
Message.Msg: I’ve got egg on my face. I predicted a Romney landslide and, instead, we ended up with an Obama squeaker. The key reason for my bum prediction is that I mistakenly believed that the 2008 surge in black, Latino, and young voter turnout would recede in 2012 to “normal” levels. Didn’t happen. These high levels of minority and young voter participation are here to stay. And, with them, a permanent reshaping of our nation’s politics. In 2012, 13% of the vote was cast by blacks. In 04, it was 11%. This year, 10% was Latino. In ’04 it was 8%. This time, 19% was cast by voters under 30 years of age. In ’04 it was 17%. Taken together, these results swelled the ranks of Obama’s three-tiered base by five to six points, accounting fully for his victory.

Message.Title: Congrats America!
Message.Msg: What a ride! Congratulations on a job well done and THANK YOU for all of your hard work these last several months. It was a momentous, historic victory for our side, delivering a clear mandate for President Obama to pursue a strong progressive agenda. Beyond the obvious electoral victories and defeats, there were a lot of winners and losers yesterday -- too many to list, in fact… but here are a few quick ones, starting with the losers. LOSERS: Right-wing billionaires and corporate special interests Make no mistake about it: The unlimited influence of Big Money in elections is an enormous and still existential threat to American democracy. But yesterday, People Power won. And, ironically, Big Money might have had a part in that. The sickening amount of money spent on yesterday’s elections no doubt played a role in raising the election’s profile… and ensuring a massive turnout of voters across the board. Because of shifting demographics (I’ll get to that more in a bit), Republicans -- especially this year’s anti-Latino, anti-woman, ultra-regressive version of them -- simply can’t survive nationally when turnout is as high across the board as it was in yesterday’s election. Redefining Rape (and “severely conservative” attitudes towards women, their health and their right to control their own bodies) Women played an integral part in President Obama’s reelection and Mitt “Binders Full of Women” Romney’s defeat. But two very big Senate upsets in the Democrats’ favor were inarguably the direct result of right-wing misogyny. GOP Senate candidates Todd Akin in Missouri and Richard Mourdock in Indiana both went down in flames. Akin, notorious for his “legitimate rape” comment and his faux scientific theory that said legitimate rapes cannot produce pregnancies, was also exposed in the final days of the campaign as having been arrested no less than eight times in aggressive anti-choice protests at women’s health clinics (PFAW’s Right Wing Watch was responsible for unearthing that vital information). Mourdock said a pregnancy that is the result of a woman’s rape is “something God intended.” So, yeah, regressive attitudes toward rape and women’s rights were big losers at the polls -- go figure. What the Republicans didn't get and still don't seem to understand is that it's not just some tone deaf comments -- it's their policies! Citizens United Everywhere it was on the ballot -- Colorado, Montana, Chicago, many places in Massachusetts -- voters by huge margins approved ballot initiatives to get unlimited corporate money OUT of elections, either by a constitutional amendment undoing the Supreme Court’s Citizens United decision or by affirming that, much to the chagrin of Mitt Romney no doubt, corporations are NOT people and are not entitled to the same constitutional rights as people. Where these initiatives were on the ballot statewide, namely in Colorado and Montana, you can be sure that they also played a role in mobilizing progressive turnout and leading to President Obama’s victory in Colorado and Democratic Senator Jon Tester’s upset win for reelection in Montana. With our continuing fight for a better Supreme Court, and the national grassroots movement to overturn Citizens United by constitutional amendment growing every day, I know that we’re on the path to take our democracy back and restore Government By the People. Voter Suppression The Right did everything it could to make voting more difficult, particularly for minority voters. But what we saw was that efforts to disenfranchise certain groups became a rallying cry to energize those very same voters. Even without all the voter ID laws, shortened early voting hours and new restrictions on voter registration drives, African American turnout was expected to wane and fall short of 2008. It didn’t. African American turnout matched that of 2008, thanks in no small part to efforts like the VESSELS program of PFAW Foundation’s African American Ministers Leadership Council -- which was responsible for making sure tens of thousands of African American voters knew the facts about voting laws in their states and were mobilized, energized to vote and gotten to the polls. The Tea Party How about this headline? “Michele Bachmann clings on to her seat but major blow for the Tea Party as key figures are beaten by Democrat challengers” Despite Republicans holding on to their House majority -- thanks to redistricting and massive amounts of post-Citizens United money poured into these races -- some of the Tea Party’s most vocal leaders in Congress were sent packin’. Allen West: Gone. Joe Walsh: No longer. In the presidential race, the Tea Party’s economic vision for America, embodied by Mitt Romney and perhaps even more definitively by Republican vice presidential candidate Paul Ryan, was also soundly defeated on the national level. Now to the WINNERS: Strong, unabashed PROGRESSIVES! Progressives have long struggled to have a real voice in the U.S. Senate. But let me tell you, the reelection of Sherrod Brown is major. Add to that the reelection of Bernie Sanders and the election of Elizabeth Warren AND Tammy Baldwin (!!!), who join fighters like Al Franken and Sheldon Whitehouse… simply put, we can now say that progressive values have a real and very powerful voice in the U.S. Senate. In the House, despite not much changing in terms of the majority, we get to welcome back progressive champion Alan Grayson. Let’s just say the Florida congressional delegation’s trade of an Allen (West) for an Alan (Grayson) is more than welcome. Equality Equality, that foundational American value, has taken a beating at the polls in the past -- particularly when it has come to the fundamental right of LGBT Americans to have their relationships recognized in the same way as the rest of Americans’. Yesterday, we reversed that trend. Maryland, Maine and Minnesota all saw victories for marriage equality and another one is on the way in Washington. As MLK said, “the arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends toward justice!” We’re on the right side of history and we’re going to keep fighting until every family and every American achieve full legal equality. Latino Voting Power Pundits said Latino voters lacked enthusiasm this year and wouldn’t show up. They said that even though Latinos have made up an increasing share of the electorate in every election, after the massive turnout in 2008 we could expect that trend to take a break this election. People For the American Way, on the other hand, knew better. YOU knew better. Yesterday the chickens came home to roost for Republicans. After years of kowtowing to the most nativist, xenophobic extremes of their base and a presidential primary that was defined in large part by outright Latino-bashing, Latino voters came out for President Obama in higher margins than any previous presidential candidate. People For the American Way invested heavily in making sure Latinos made their voices heard at the polls, especially in swing states. It was a bet we really went “all in” on -- and clearly it was one that paid off. We’ll continue this important work to make sure Latinos continue to have a welcoming home in the progressive movement. Young Voting Power The pundits also said young voters wouldn’t turn out like they did in 2008. Wrong again. Young voters as a share of the electorate increased from 2008. The Millennial Generation is establishing a strong habit of exercising its right to vote, and this bodes very well for the progressive movement moving forward. Our affiliate People For the American Way Foundation’s Young People For program waged a large-scale nonpartisan “Arrive with 5” campaign to encourage voting among this crucial demographic. And, finally... People For the American Way America won yesterday, and the American Way won yesterday. Important reforms passed in President Obama’s first term -- health care reform, financial reform -- would not have been realized had he failed to get reelected. Voters saved the Supreme Court from Mitt Romney’s would-be nominees and now the Court could very well be taken off the dangerous and extreme right-wing path it’s been on in recent years, with President Obama filling potential vacancies in his second term. And America made a decisive choice to reject the disturbing extremism, both economic and social, of the modern Republican Party. But for all the “winners” yesterday who were vindicated in their predictions or got elected to office, I can truly say that People For the American Way, this organization and its supporters, including you, stands out as a unique victor because of where we chose to invest our resources and the amazing impact it had in this election. Long Live America!
